newsitem.title: UK: North Sea crude steady, Dated holds recent range.
newsitem.headline: North Sea crude steady, Dated holds recent range.

text.p: North Sea crudes were steady on Wednesday, Dated Brent holding on to substantial premiums to forward paper values amid thin prompt supply and further delays to Ekofisk loadings, traders said.
One of two cargoes turning wet was kept by BP, who sold it to an NWE refiner for Mar Brent +34 cents a barrel, four cents above Tuesday's highest deal. A second Feb 20-22 Brent was clocked to Stasco.
A Feb 12-14 Brent fetched Mar Brent +25 cents in a deal between Wall Street traders, still within a recent range, dealers said.
"The market is looking pretty stable," said a major North Sea producer.

Problems commissioning a pipeline tie-in of the U.K. Fulmar field to Norway's Ekofisk stream was compounding week-long delays caused by a shutdown in January, prompting some to look for alternatives to cover February requirements, traders said.
Mar Brent slipped four cents to $22.39 a barrel by 1825 GMT, but intermonth spreads were a couple of cents firmer, Mar/Apr rising to +46/+48 cents.
Other grades were mostly quiet, with little remaining from February programmes to be sold, but 600,000 barrels of Oseberg loading Feb 22-24 fetched a healthy 50-cent premium to Brent.
In the Mediteranean, Urals was still seen under pressure after trade at Dated Brent -79 cents cif Genoa on Tuesday.
West African markets were fairly quiet ahead of the release of the March loading programmes for Nigerian crudes, expected later Wednesday or early Thursday.
